issues.title: Security Consideration: Mutual Authentication of the TraT Request
issues.author: PieterKas
issues.body:
The requirement that clients must be pre-registered feels like it perpetuates the problem we see with workload identities, where the client identity may not be known ahead of time. This is not unlike the problems we see with wallets and the need for some way to let clients authenticate without being pre-registered. 

I wonder if we can remove this requirement and instead rely on some form of authentication where the trust is in the credential issuer. For example, with SPIFFE, there is an authority that issues the credential to the workload, so as long as the client presents a credential issued by the authority, it could be trusted (provided the authority is trusted).

issues.author: appsdesh
issues.body:
Can we clarify in the examples how do internal services authorize the Transaction tokens?
1. Are all the internal services bootstrapped with the token service public key?

comments.author: obfuscoder
comments.body:
I don't like to make iss claim mandatory. If all services operate within the same trust boundary, they already know their trusted authorization server and an iss claim would just add clutter and unnecessary data to the token. Also it would mean that one had to already trust some data within the transaction token before being able to validate its signature. This could lead to a rogue component to send requests to an internal service with carefully crafted transaction tokens with an iss pointing to another server the rogue component has control over. To prevent injecting rogue iss, the internal service would need to validate the provided iss value with a preconfigured list of allowed ones.

In our environment (trust boundary) where we are using internal tokens for transactions, the internal services have the authorization server's host name configured. Internal services can decide to pull (and cache) the jwks from the well-known url and validate the tokens locally or they can use the token introspection endpoint of the authorization server for validating the token. Validating the internal/transaction tokens with token introspection is useful for some sensitive operations and has the benefit that this validation can fail if for instance the access token the transaction token was derived from got revoked or the authentication context associated with the tokens got flagged.

issues.title: Separate transaction tokens from JWT
issues.author: jricher
issues.body:
To me, the real value here is the semantics around the payload, and less directly tied to the JWT format as its container. In particular, it seems like the payload could benefit from some of the disclosure capabilities of things like SD-JWT to allow the system to mask certain values from some parties within the trust domain.

Consequently, perhaps the document should focus on the payload and semantics, or explicitly show ties to both JWT and SD-JWT (and maybe CWT and others?) from the payload definition.

comments.author: gffletch
comments.body: That is an interesting restructuring to the doc. Basically a conceptual section and then bindings to particular formats allowing for profiles to other encodings? Is that the general idea?

comments.author: obfuscoder
comments.body:
Are we considering opaque token formats as an alternative as well? Those formats could not be verified (e.g. signature check) by the workloads locally, but would require incorporating Token Introspection to get the data. For performance reasons, the format should at least be defined as self contained and verifiable locally. CWT as well as (SD-)JWT would have these properties. In the IETF meeting protobuf was mentioned. As far as I know, protobuf does not have this property, so I don't see it as a fitting candidate.

We also need to consider interoperability. If the spec allowed for multiple formats (or even leaves the format out of the specification), generic libraries/frameworks to implement the protocol would need to support not just one but a lot of formats or even make the format (serialization/deserialization) pluggable. Although this might be a good idea anyway, it tends to be more complex.

In regards to selective disclosure: The purpose of the transaction token is to pass it along the transaction call chain. So if there is specific data of the original presented Access Token not to be disclosed in the transaction token, the TTS would simply not add it in the transaction token when issuing it. Although a workload can choose to exchange the transaction token for another one, the purpose was to narrow the scope to further limit the access which the new transaction token could be used for. At this point the new transaction token could contain even less information than the original transaction token. I don't think that there should be more information disclosed at this point. That's why I don't think that SD-JWTs would have an application here.

On the other hand, I do see an application for a transaction token which contains specific information for specific workloads along the call chain. I can see some similarities to Rich Authorization Requests (RAR) where there can be PII/resource identifiers in the transaction token which should only be visible to some workloads even if the transaction token is passed along through all participating workloads.

comments.author: PieterKas
comments.body: Opaque tokens and selective disclosure are advanced features that we are deferring to a future specification and leaving it out of scope for this draft.

issues.title: Transaction Tokens for S2S calls
issues.author: dteleguin
issues.body:
> Cryptographically protected Txn-Tokens ensure that downstream workloads cannot make unauthorized modifications to such information, and cannot make spurious calls without the presence of an external trigger.

What about legitimate (non-spurious) calls without the presence of an external trigger?

A transaction might be initiated by an internal component (e.g. triggered by a scheduler). In this case, there will be no external context (`req_ctx`) and no user (human) identity. However, transaction details (`purp` and `azd`) might still be relevant.

Can TX Tokens cover this use case as well? The benefits will be unified token issuance and verification process for both external- and internal-initiated transactions. The only alternative in the OAuth world I could think of is the Client Credentials Grant, but it doesn't specify how to push transaction-specific data. Also, the result will be an Access Token and not a Txn-Token, which assumes that downstream workloads must be able to understand both.

Maybe slightly unrelated, but it is also a bit unclear how should we communicate the desired `azd` and `purp` to the Txn-Token Service? Or is it assumed that everything should be derived from the external token + `rctx`?

comments.author: gffletch
comments.body:
Transaction Tokens can definitely be used with legitimate calls that don't have an external trigger. The key element from an authorization perspective, is "who is allowed to request an transaction token" and "for what purpose(s)". If any service can request a transaction token, then it's important to limit the scope of how that transaction token can be used. In other words, we wouldn't want the logging service to be able to request a transaction service for the purpose of transferring crypto from a user's account.

I would argue that there is still a `req_ctx` in this case, it may just contain different claims. I would expect downstream systems to want to know the originating workload that requested the transaction token.

As for `azd`, I agree that there are use cases where that needs to be specified to the Transaction Token service.

Great points on areas where we need to enhance the specification.

comments.author: obfuscoder
comments.body:
Reviewing this issue, I can see a relation with #62. As it has been established that requesting Txn-Tokens without an external trigger is needed. however, the current spec requires an Access token to be presented in the subject_token parameter and the question is, how an internal batch process would obtain this. @dteguin (and me in the related issue #62) mentioned Client credentials grant for obtaining the AT. However, client credentials grant based ATs may not be related to users referred to with the sub claim, so it may be a challenge to issue Txn-Tokens with a user-related sub when the client credentials grant based AT does not contain one.

In #62 I gave an example where a batch processor might be able to present an expired Txn-Token, but there are still scenarios where no AT can be presented in the subject_token parameter or where the presented subject_token does not contain the information necessary to fill and issue the Txn-Token. This information needs to be provided somehow to the TTS. If this information must be part of the subject_token or somehow be obtainable by the TTS via parts of the subject_token content, it should at least be mentioned in the spec.

Personally, I'd like to see an option where the TTS can be called without a subject_token as input and instead providing the necessary information via additional parameters (e.g. sub within the req_ctx). It goes without saying, that this type of Token issuance should only be allowed to a very limited set of authenticated clients which have a special trust relationship with the TTS.

issues.author: gffletch
issues.body:
I suspect in many cases the AS that issues an access_token used to obtain an Txn-Token is going to be different than the Transaction Token Service. In that context, the issuer of the 'subject' of the transaction token is different than the issuer of the transaction token itself. 

Section 3.2.3 of RFC 9493 allows for the specification of an issuer and sub within the `sub_id` object. 

Should we require this format? or just leave out of scope of the specification what values are present in the `sub_id` claim of the transaction token?

comments.author: bc-pi
comments.body:
I would definitely not require that format. 

And would again suggest that RFC 9493 isn't needed in the Txn-Token context and [JWT's subject](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc7519#section-4.1.2) good enough.

comments.author: gffletch
comments.body:
My concern with relying on the JWT's subject is that the Transaction Token is issued by the Transaction Token Service which is potentially different than the AS that say issued the access token from which the `sub` claim is determined. In that context, I think the Transaction Token should carry the issuer of the `sub` claim which means the default `sub` and `iss` claims of the JWT are not sufficient.

Or if the entity requesting the Transaction token is the service that receives inbound mail, and that service wants a transaction token with a purpose of `mail.inbox.delivery`, is the Transaction Token Service the correct issuer of the `sub` which is an email address?

comments.author: gffletch

comments.author: gffletch
comments.body:
So that assumes that the `sub` claim MUST be unique within the single trust domain as identified by the `aud` claim. issues.title: Long-living Access Token needed for internal batch processes/offline tasks?
issues.author: obfuscoder
issues.body:
The current spec states:

"Even for long-running "batch" jobs, a longer lived access token should be used to initiate the request to the batch endpoint. It then obtains short-lived Txn-Tokens that may be used to authorize the call to downstream services in the call-chain."

I assume the reasoning behind this is that there would be no need to define a Txn-Token Request without an original Access Token. However, I think that creating long-living Access Tokens just for the purpose of exchanging them for short-lived Txn-Tokens and then throwing them away can be considered wasteful (energy costs). Every internally originating job would need at least two calls instead of just one to obtain the Txn-Token.

Keeping those long-living Access Tokens around to re-use them for longer time is usually not useful for batch processes as those processes operate on a lot of user accounts in quick succession. Maintaining all those Access Tokens in memory is often not feasible. Neither is a storage system. I also think that using long-living Access Tokens in this scenario can add security risks. Those Access Tokens could leak and another party could use them to create Txn-Tokens or access resources the Access Token was meant for.

In our own implementation of a Txn-Service, the Txn-Service (Token Exchange) is also providing the Token endpoint and allows specific internal clients to use the Client Credentials Grant Type (mTLS client certificates) to obtain Txn-Tokens right away. The necessary input parameters are essentially a combination of the Token Request based on Client Credentials Grant and Token Exchange with a Txn-Token profile.

Is it possible to extend the Txn-Token Service interface to allow Txn-Token Requests without the Access Token as input? This would essentially mean to define a Txn-Token profile for the Token endpoint in addition to the Token Exchange protocol.

comments.author: gffletch
comments.body:
So a couple of thoughts here:

1. I believe the Txn-Token Service (TTS) must be able to issue Txn-Tokens without a previously issued access_token. Think about a use case where email is being delivered to a mail box. SMTP does not carry the access token that authorized the sending of the email. In that context, the in-bound email server needs to be able to request a Txn-Token for the purpose of delivering the email to the specified inbox.
2. The general intent for keeping Txn-Tokens very short lived is to remove the need for revocation. Revocation is difficult for any token system (see the issuer-holder-verifier efforts in this space). Given that the vast majority of transactions complete in a very short timeframe, keeping the life-time of the Txn-Token short makes a lot of sense.
3. There are some edge cases where a longer lived Txn-Token may be beneficial or required.  Say for instance a user asks for their account to be deleted (GDPR) and the Txn-Token needs to live for multiple days? even though the underlying identity system may have cleaned up the user identifier data. That said, these edge cases should be vetted very carefully as there is a security risk if a Txn-Token lives for a long time and hence can be replayed potentially in compromising ways.

comments.author: obfuscoder
comments.body:
The use cases you mention are pretty much what we had to implement.

1. For incoming mails we have a mail delivery agent which wants to use the mail storage system service to store the mail in the user mailbox. In order to write to the mailbox of a user, the delivery agent needs a Txn-Token with the sub of the user. The delivery agent asks the TTS about a Txn-Token and presents its client credentials and the mail address of the recipient/user. The TTS allows issuing Txn-Tokens to the delivery agent. There is no long-living access token involved. The issued Txn-Token is short lived (1 minute in our deployments).

3. Whenever a user cancels their contract, we have to keep the data for some time (number of days depending on type of data, legal restrictions, etc.) after the delete operations are performed. The delayed delete operation is done by batch processes. Now, instead of creating and storing long-living access tokens which could be leaked and abused elsewhere, we decided to retain the short-lived Txn-Tokens and allow only those batch processes to ask the TTS to issue new Txn-Tokens for already expired Txn-Tokens to perform the actual delete operation which requires a valid and not expired Txn-Token when calling the storage system services.

So my argument is against using (and potentially abusing) long-living access tokens, and instead for allowing expired Txn-Tokens to be presented to the TTS to re-issue Txn-Tokens for the purpose of finalizing a delayed operation.

comments.author: tulshi
comments.body: I do not think we should allow the use of expired TraTs to authorize the issuance of new TraTs. This can be abused for token replay attacks, and negates the security we get through short-lived TraTs.

comments.author: obfuscoder
comments.body:
@tulshi Good point. In order to get a new TraTs, the caller needs proper client authentication (e.g. SPIFFE, mTLS, or Basic Auth credentials). My point was to only allow specific authenticated clients the exchange of expired TraTs. It is true that if those clients get hacked themselves (and the client authentication can be done by an attacker) new TraTs can be created and abused.

However, longer living TraTs have also the risk of being abused with replay attacks. I think the risk for replay attacks with longer living TraTs is even higher as an attacker would just need to get hold of the long-living TraTs and does not have the need to renew it.

comments.author: gffletch
comments.body:
Using an expired Txn-Token has some interesting properties. Assuming the `purp` claim is narrowly scoped, the TTS should NOT issue a new Txn-Token with a different `purp` value. 

I would probably recommend creating very specific `purp` values for this use case and then only allowing specific clients to request a Txn-Token where the `subject_token` value is the expired Txn-Token. This is currently allowed within the spec... the question might be whether we want to explicitly encourage or discourage such behavior.

In my mind, using an expired Txn-Token is a bit like requesting a replacement Txn-Token except the processing rules are even more strict.

comments.author: obfuscoder
comments.body:
Indeed, the spec does not say anything about whether and how the TTS is validating the txn token before issuing a replacement txn-token. So presenting an already expired txn-token can be accepted based on the authenticated client, purpose and scope. After all, it can be a specifically defined policy.

I recommend that we at least acknowledge this case in the spec and give guidance when to use it. As we also have the case of not presenting any token when requesting a txn-token (see #53), I think that as long as a workload is in possession of a txn-token - even if it is expired - we should recommend to present it when requesting replacement txn-tokens. It should be the decision of the TTS whether to accept the expired txn-token and not of the workload (the workload could just take the subject from the expired token and present it as the subject_token to the TTS).

One additional aspect came to our attention. There are actually two cases for expired txn-tokens:

1. The exp claim says it is expired, but the signature is still valid
2. The signature is not valid (anymore) as the key used to sign the token is not available anymore

Depending on how frequently a TTS is rotating its key material, the second case might occur for such long running processes like deleting account data several weeks after the customer has cancelled their contract. For instance our TTS implementation is rotating the keys daily. Only the next, current and previous signing keys are provided to workloads (via JWKS uri). Even if a workload is not able to verify the signature of a txn-token it received several weeks ago, the TTS might still be able to keep the old key material for a longer period so that it can at least validate the signature of those txn-tokens.

comments.author: obfuscoder
comments.body: Should this issue be consolided together with #111

comments.author: PieterKas
comments.body: Long running batch processes are out of scope and we will defer this to a time when we have more experience with transaction tokens.

issues.title: audience REQUIRED for just one trust domain?
issues.author: obfuscoder
issues.body:
This issue is somewhat related to the aud claim comment I made earlier via mail to the authors.

The spec states that audience parameter is REQUIRED in the Txn-Token request. It contains the trust domain. To my understanding, every trust domain has a single (logical) Txn-Service. A Txn-Service is usually configured to only issue Txn-Tokens to one and only one trust domain. Also the authenticating clients which the Txn-Service accepts in incoming requests are part of that trust domain. After all, they have been registered within that trust domain. It might be possible that the Txn-Service is used in multiple trust domains. In those scenarios I fully agree that the audience parameter is REQUIRED. My guess is, though, that the most deployed setup will incorporate a single trust domain.

> What is the benefit of making the aud claim optional?

Mostly brevity reasons. Also, if it is defined as REQUIRED, it will be enforced by 3rd party libraries which a company might want to integrate in their components/services. This essentially forces the company (albeit using Txn-Tokens within their trust domain only internally) to define and set the aud claim without added benefit.

Having aud REQUIRED also implies that the value needs to be validated somehow. I think this aspect should be mentioned in the spec, if it is really required. So every Token service must have the audience parameter validated as well as every service/worker receiving a Txn-Token must validate the aud claim against a configured accepted value (or list of values).

Embedded with the Authorization Server

Pros:
* the `iss` claim is the same as the authorization server and likely already known by downstream workloads

issues.title: A dummy transaction token - useful for debugging
issues.author: ashayraut
issues.body: There is no concept of placeholder or temporary token here. Sometimes the call chain breaks i.e some service in the chain doesn't propagate the token in header, either due to a bug or unexpected code change, in such case, the service that didn't receive token from caller can generate a dummy unsigned token with caller information (that missed to send token) and pass to next service.  So if A -> B -> C -> D and B misses to forward the header token, then C generates a dummy token with info about B and passes to D. This increases visibility for debugging. The service at end will find that its not real token but it can audit which service broke the call chain and can involve B directly to debug. Unsigned dummy token cannot be trusted hence MUST not be used for making authorization decision and MUST be used only for auditing/logging.

comments.body:
This is awesome feedback!

Some questions that come into my mind:

---

I suppose C will only generate the dummy token when it doesn't need to validate it or require specific caller information from A or B which it cannot securely extract from the request. Otherwise the call from B -> C would result in an authn/z error and fail - no need for an replacement token, is it? 

---

If B can generate dummy tokens, how can it be prevented that it does not generate a dummy token which looks like a legit token and impersonate users like this? E.g. B is compromised and generates dummy tokens to request informations from other workloads that in fact accept dummy tokens? 

Maybe this question is leading to the next one:

---

How are dummy tokens distinguished from real ones? Is there a risk developers by mistake consider dummy tokens as trusted?

comments.author: ashayraut
comments.body:
> Otherwise the call from B -> C would result in an authn/z error and fail - no need for an replacement token, is it?

Yes. If C is validating token, then it can deny request. If C is more of an intermediate passthrough type service, then C will rely on D to deny/allow, in which case B has to send a token.

> How are dummy tokens distinguished from real ones? Is there a risk developers by mistake consider dummy tokens as trusted?

Yes, that is the most important aspect. In general, as Hyrum's law suggests, once token is out there, we won't be able to control who uses it for what purpose. Our recommendation can be that - a token validator (e.g. Service D) MUST always use the claims in token ONLY IF validate signature exists. comments.author: obfuscoder

We are actually facing this issue in our current deployments. Although we have some workloads which already receive, validate and forward TraTs, they are being called by other workloads which do not present TraTs yet and on the other end, they call other workloads which just ignore the TraTs and don't pass them along yet. So during this rollout phase (which can take months or even years) it is quite common that TraTs are getting lost frequently and no workload can actually enforce TraT validation.

issues.title: Key rotation guidance
issues.author: ashayraut
issues.body: Key rotation is interesting. If you rotate key at time T1 and Tx token services starts to issue tokens with new key at same time, we have to callout that it should do it at T1+X where X is the SLA for ensuring all services that validate signature will receive the new public key to verify signature. Keys can be shared out of band. One idea is to generate two pairs and two corresponding public keys will be available with services all the time. Tx Token service will have two private pairs available. Lets say PrvtKey-1 and PrvtKey-2 are with issuers. PrvtKey-1 should be used from T1 to T1+24hrs and Key-2 from T1+24 to T1+48hrs. When Tx token switches from Key-1 to 2, it doesn't have to worry about some service not having public key for key-2 to validate the token. This way key synchronization is out of band + key rotation happens frequently which keeps key rotation machinery well-tested. Generally there is no need to rotate key every 24hrs so we can choose to relax that but even if we have to force rotate key then we have to make sure force rotated key (i.e new key pair) should be used to mint tokens only when we can guarantee that those tokens can be validated.

comments.author: PieterKas
comments.body:
This issue references two topics:

1. Key rotation
2. The cost of performing verification.

On (1), there is ample guidance in the OAuth RFCs that we can reference. is there anything new or specific we want to addd that is not in the OAuth drafts already?

For (2), I am not convinced that there are substantially more cryptographic operations. If a set of microservices was just passing Access Tokens, it would still be parsing and verifying the signatures on those. Now it is verifying signatures on transaction tokens instead. Although there might be a small increase, it may not be an order of magnitude (unless access tokens was passed around and not verified, which may be true for TraTs as well). I would also hesitate to provide guidance on which cryptographic algorithms to use, especially as new post quantum algorithms are going to be around. 

Some thoughts:

(1) Add a section on key rotation and reference existing RFCs (e.g. key rotation should be performed according to guidelines in RFC.... and RFC....)
(2) Don't make any recommendations on crypto algorithms.

If we provide refresh token which is signed and contains the original token inside it, then refresh token when passed to Tx token service, then Tx token service can verify if 1) refresh token is signed with its private key, 2) the token inside will be expired but it can still read the token and verify caller's identity is associated with all the claims or not, if yes, then it can get new Tx token with same claims or it can get new token but claims that are associated to them and not the exact claims present in the token inside refresh token. Because sometimes the service might just want to use the claims of its caller (as long as its permitted to do so) rather than new token. 

For example, if an internal service C is called by A and B, and C is allowed to make requests to D for tax or accounting purpose. 
A->C
B->C
C->D
A is allowed to make request and request Tx token for tax purpose.
B is allowed to make request and request Tx token for accounting purpose.
C is allowed for both accounting and tax purpose because is a common service


Now,  C simply wants to use usage claim based on who called - A or B. C can do so by passing token generated for A or B to D. But if C is a workflow that pauses for more than TTL of Tx token, then token expires and it loses all the context about claims associated with A and B. In such case, before going on long pause, C can request refresh token from Tx Token service by passing original valid token it receives. It requests this token before going into long pause. It receives refresh token which it will use when it resumes. Refresh token will have longer TTL. Tx Token can configure TTL per use case and/or per caller (e.g. C). Tx token service will include claims in the input valid token in the refresh token but the refresh token cannot be used to access data from any service. Services should ignore refresh tokens in case someone (C) tries to use it directly. C has to make an exchange and pass refresh token to TxToken issuer service to get new token to pass to D.

issues.title: Audience, scope & purpose
issues.author: arndt-s
issues.body:
From IETF chat: "Scope, audience and purpose claims all limit the transaction token but at different levels. I wonder if this can be simplified?"

Workload developers that validate transaction tokens currently would need to validate all 3 of these claims just for the sake of knowing if the transaction token is acceptable in their context. Authorization decisions based on azd and rctx then come on top of that.

comments.author: gffletch
comments.body:
I'm a little confused regarding the inclusion of scope as 'scope' is only an input parameter to the Transaction Token Service and that parameter name is used because of the profiling of the Token Exchange spec. 

The transaction token itself only has `aud` and `purp` and the point of using a different name than 'scope' for `purp` is that the semantics are slightly different. A transaction token should have a very fine-grained purpose and most scope values are not fine-grained. 

A workload should only need to validate the `aud` field to know that the transaction token is part of it's trust domain and secondly the `purp` claim to evaluate if the stated purpose is something that the workload participates in. Not also, that a workload is not required to process the `purp` claim from an authorization point of view. I can depend on what the request is and risk, etc. 

The intended authorization model is that the Transaction Token Service acts as a primary PDP when issuing the transaction token and then each workload can run it's own policy (if desired) to further evaluate the validity of the request.

comments.author: arndt-s
comments.body:
You are right @gffletch, `scope` is not part of the transaction token and just a parameter of token exchange that results in the `aud` claim.

My thinking during the talk was whether `aud` is truly necessary. Once the signature check has passed (either based on issuer claim + metatabase + JWKS or trust bundle) the trust domain is implicit IMO. Also, what if the signature check passed but the audience does not match with the signing keys? Are workloads expected to check and deny then?

Related, do we expect workloads to just accept transaction tokens of a single trust domain or do we see use cases where incoming transaction tokens are part of different trust domains than the workload itself?

comments.author: gffletch
comments.body:
So a couple of thoughts... I do think that `aud` is necessary as it's possible there could be multiple issuers that are all part of the single trust domain. For me, this makes the audience an easier way to determine the validity of the token to the workload.

As for transaction tokens that cross trust domain boundaries, I don't think we want to enable that. I'd prefer we leverage the cross domain OAuth work and the wimse token translation work to get a transaction token issued by the trust domain.

We may need to expand some thinking around authorization models and how they fit in with transaction tokens.

comments.author: obfuscoder
comments.body: Note: Although `scope` may not be part of the TraT definition, we decided to include the `scope` value in our implementation. For us, this value should at least be validated by workloads if there isn't a more specific purpose given in the TraT.

comments.author: gffletch
comments.body: @obfuscoder is there a reason you chose not to just set the purpose of the given TraT to the scope ? Semantic mismatch?

comments.author: obfuscoder
comments.body:
@gffletch We had already an implementation of transaction tokens in place before we became aware of the transaction token draft. Our implementation was a bit more aligned with Token Exchange where the scope is copied (or narrowed down) to the internally used transaction token. So most deployments rely on having the scope in the "scope" claim. There is also pretty good library support for the scope claim already.

That said, it might not be an issue of semantics, but rather of ownership. At least in our implementation, scope values are defined (and owned) by the services which enforce the scope (also in internal calls using transaction tokens) when the internal microservice interface is called. Purpose, on the other hand, is more bound to the use case which needs to be fulfilled and the definition of those use cases will rather be done by the external endpoints (BFFs) and thus also owned by them. The internal microservices will then need to be configured to support purposes defined by several external endpoints. So it might still be worth, having the microservice check the scope it defined to be present when calling its API on top of validating the purpose.

comments.author: tulshi
comments.body: I've worked in environments earlier where the name "scope" in internal tokens caused enormous confusion with OAuth scopes from external systems.

comments.author: gffletch
comments.body: I'm not sure we need to do anything here. The input `scope` value (either explicitly or from the input token) can be put in the `tctx` claim and used by downstream services. The spec does not prevent what @obfuscoder has implemented.

Based on conversations at OSW 2025, there was a proposal to remove the restriction of limiting the transaction token lifetime to be less than the access token. The proposal based on conversations with George is to move it into the security considerations and remove the constraint.

Topic for discussion at IETF 122

comments.author: gffletch
comments.body:
I'm ok with leaving the current wording and changing it from a MUST to a SHOULD (meaning the transaction token lifetime SHOULD NOT extend beyond the lifetime of the access token). And then also adding a section to the Security Considerations from when it may be ok to extend beyond the lifetime of the authorization token.

I'm happy to take this work... I think I can get to it this week.

comments.author: FrodeI
comments.body:
Hello, I raised this question at the OSW (and thank you for a good discussion). I understand the concern that the use case for transaction tokens are for a single operation only, and as such long lifetimes does not make sense and will only increase the security risk. However the lifetime of the access token is commonly understood to specify when the operation can be started (though as far as I can tell, RFC6749 actually doesn't say much on this). Many applications however have operations exposed through APIs that take several seconds or even minutes to complete. The client can not be expected to always know how long an operation will take to complete, and can only be reasonably sure that the access token it's presenting when invoking the operation is valid. For operations where multiple internal services are involved, where some services uses Replacement Txn-Token flow as described in section 2.5.2 of the draft, the result may also be that some internal services succeed in requesting transaction tokens, while later steps fail because the original access token is now expired.

I think text in section 9.1 addresses this well, but I would suggest that 2.3 does not bind the transaction token lifetime to the access token lifetime at all, and omit the second sentence in that section completely.

comments.author: pdvrieze
comments.body: I have been doing research on a similar problem (in the context of process management software). Here the transaction serves also as a tag. But significantly, it would be possible to revoke the transaction by the initiating system. If further security is required it would be preferable to limit the tokens to a single audience, but allow the delegating (resource) service to exchange its own token for one it can use as client (while retaining the transaction information/tag).

comments.author: DecoreyA
comments.body:
I'm ok with leaving the current wording and changing it from BY ORDER a MUST to a SHOULD (meaning the transaction token lifetime SHOULD NOT extend beyond the lifetime of the access token). And then also adding a section to the Security Considerations from when it may be ok to extend beyond the lifetime of the authorization token.

I'm happy to take this work... I think I can get to it this week.

comments.author: pdvrieze
comments.body: @DecoreyA The question is more whether it should be limited to the lifetime of the access token or an underlying authorization. This is made harder by the assumption that refresh tokens do not per se have a lifetime (but can be invalidated any time). In other words, is there a way to "renew" the transaction token as long as the underlying authorization is still valid (also noting that some authorizations can be organizational, not by a "user").

issues.title: Requester Context - req_ip
issues.author: dhs-BI
issues.body:
Reviewing the -05 draft, section 5.2.2 identifies the `req_ip` as the IP of the originating user.  However, the bullets identify `req_ip` as belonging to the "end-user or robotic process...".  I find this to be ambiguous about what the `req_ip` represents.  This is further complicated by the fact that the user's IP address may not be available to the call stack because the request has been proxied through one or more devices, obfuscating the user's original IP address.

I have two questions:

1. Can the language around the `req_ip` be tightened up to make it clear that it is either the IP of the end user when issued in exchange for an AT, and it represents the workload's IP when the workload is requesting a replacement txn_token?  The context of a txn_token `req_wl` will make it clear that the `req_ip` is the client (iff `req_wl` is a single element), or the calling workload (iff `req_wl` is > 1 element).
2. Can we add an imperative that the ```req_ip``` for the first txn_token SHOULD NOT be the IP of a proxy or gateway, _e.g._ by using the `X-Forwarded-For` header?

If the authors think these additions are valuable, I can write the PR.

comments.author: gffletch
comments.body:
@dhs-BI  Getting the originating user IP is always a best effort endeavor. Having the value is useful in many risk calculations. Of course things like Apple Private Relay reduce some of that value. Given that the presence of the `req_ip` claim is optional in the `rctx` object (which is also optional). The implementation can determine if it has a usable enough IP to add to the context.

Do you think we need clarity, either in the definition or security considerations, to address this?

comments.author: deansaxe
comments.body: I would include some language in the doc to address the fact that the IP is a best effort guess and may not actually represent the real IP address because of proxies, etc.

comments.author: ashayraut
comments.body: Agree, IpAddress isn't really reliable. In general, as part of governance, we have to be careful on what we add in these tokens because the tokens protect by default to entire call graph and we may not want to propagate this IpAddress everywhere. Yes, we can encrypt the value to ensure customer's ipAddress isn't exposed to entire graph but also if someone is allowed to get decryption key, still do we have clarity on how they will use this IpAddress for access control. Won't those access control rules break easily or even not scale when there are X millions of customers with Y number of devices.

comments.author: gffletch
comments.body:
The purpose of the `rctx` object is to provide useful information to downstream workloads to inform any local authorization/risk decisions at the workload. To that end, `req_ip` can be a valuable claim albeit with some privacy implications. 

Outside of the requesting workload, I'm wondering if there is significant value is defining other claim names or just allowing the deployment to use whatever names they want for their specific requirements.

Thoughts?

issues.title: Requester Context - authn
issues.author: dhs-BI
issues.body:
In the description of the `authn` parameter of the requester context, it is described as a StringOrURI uniquely identifying the method used to authenticate.  In 5.2.3.1 there is an example that includes the context as `urn:ietd:rfc:6749`, indicating authn via OAuth.  (I'd call this authZ...) 

Should this be defined more concretely?  I am concerned that this is pretty open ended and may not accurately represent the authentication in use.  For example, I can see a use case where the workload needs to know that the user has used a phishing resistant authenticator to authenticate and the client has authorized access using OAuth.  In this case would the context be `urn:ietd:rfc:6749` or `prMFA` or something else entirely?  

There's an argument to be made that this may not make any difference since the tokens are all used within a single trust domain which could define whatever strings they way for the `authn` parameter.

comments.author: PieterKas
comments.body: I think the argument that this can be treated withing a trust domain is valid and there is no need to add additional information.

issues.title: Expanding scope of permitted actions
issues.author: dhs-BI
issues.body:
Section 7.5.1 states, "SHOULD NOT enable modification to asserted values that expand the scope of permitted actions".  This seems overly permissive, is there a reason the sentence does not begin with "MUST NOT"?

Section 7.5.2 appears to have what I would consider the correct verbiage in the final sentence, "[...] MUST NOT increase the authorization surface [...]".

comments.author: pdvrieze
comments.body: There is actually a use case that hits this. From a minimal permissions perspective it should be possible for the delegate service to perform actions that its caller cannot. However in such cases this client scoped permission can still be specified/determined on the creation of the transaction (independently it may or may not be a good idea to hide these scopes from the token).

comments.author: PieterKas
comments.body: We should not add more scope than the original Access Token. Add clarification.

comments.author: pdvrieze
comments.body:
@PieterKas What I am thinking of is (in the context of services called by a process engine) the following:
- Take 4 services A, B, C, and D (and call sequences: A→B, B→C, C→D) and corresponding tokens
  - A→B : T1
  - B→C : T2
  - C→D: T3
- A is the initiating service that starts the transaction (for example a process engine).
- Updates to `D` are sensitive, and `B` should not be trusted to directly invoke `D` (it has no need to either - minimal permissions)
- In such a case it would be an option to have the following permission model
- T1:
  - permits A access to B with a given scope (client and audience could be bound)
  - permits B to exchange T1 for T2 (with the pre-specified permissions):
    - permit direct access by B to C for the specified scope
    - permit exchange by C for a new token (T3):
      - C is permitted to access D (with given scope)
- T2:
  - permits B access to C with a given scope (client and audience could be bound)
  - permits C to exchange T2 for T3:
    - C is permitted to access D (with given scope)
- T3:
  - permits C to access D

If we consider that token exchange is designed to alter the security context and permissions (including client bound tokens - e.g. DPoP) then it makes sense to allow for specifying (in some way this is therefore still narrowing) permissions for a service lower in the invocation chain. As to context, imagine that service B is an external service, or closed source software with limited trustworthiness (Service C can perform the appropriate checks before invoking D).

issues.title: Modelling OnBehalfOf use cases
issues.author: ashayraut
issues.body:
How are we thinking of modeling "on behalf of" use cases?

As Tx token carries the identity of the actor, a service deep down in the call chain in SOA, can verify that actor for which data is being requested, is actually signed in or not. However, often a Customer Service (CS) agent is the actor that is initiating a request on behalf of the customer, then in such cases, identity of the CS agent is definitely captured but not the identity of the real customer, who's data is going to be accessed as part of the request. Does the real customerId/customerInfo suppose to go in tctx field?

I'm thinking if we should model this more explicitly to say there is optional OnBehalfOf field that represents that actor that triggered request is acting on behalf of someone else. Tx token issuer will need a way to assert that actor is really working with that customer or not but that is something the company/domain owners have to setup. e.g. if there is authoritative service that contains mapping of CS Agent -> Customers, they are working with, then Tx token issuer could call that service and pull the information and add the customer.

comments.author: PieterKas
comments.body: On-behalf-of information can be embedded in a transaction token. The specific details of the on behalf of scenario is out of scope of this draft, but can be adressed in a different draft once the community has more experience with these kinds of flows.

comments.body:
@ashayraut is issue #184 a duplicate of this? I think both can be handled the same way. I don't believe there is anything stopping the TTS from adding an `act` claim to the Txn-token if it needs to represent the OnBehalfOf concept.

I also agree with Pieter that right now there is no real consensus for how this concept should be represented in tokens so trying add it explicitly seems premature.

comments.author: ashayraut
comments.body: Yeah the #184 is related in a way. Let me draft a proposal document on how this could potentially work based on what we are thinking for our company. We can discuss that in detail.

issues.title: Introducing a concept of authoritative context provider
issues.author: ashayraut
issues.body:
Tx Token Issuer is going to connect with some authoritative service in order to get data to add in 'tctx' field. Our RFC draft says "Txn-Tokens are primarily used to assure identity and context for a transaction, and the content of this field is a critical part of that context".  But there is guidance around how Tx Token can get this information. Often it will require to connect some service. It should make sure that - the other service is verified, the channel to connect to that service is secure. Also Tx token needs a clear contract between TxToken->Context Provider so that its clear what TxToken can pass to Context Provider and what it will expect in return.

On that we also have to think failure modes. If there are many context providers and one of them don't respond, then will TxToken continue generating tctx field with whatever data is available or completely fail token issuance request. It will be mostly left to implementation but RFC provides no guidance.

comments.author: PieterKas
comments.body: The above feels more like implementation details that will vary across systems and are not needed for interoperability (different TTS implementations may behave differently for the above scenarios). Defining implementation details is beyond the scope of this specification.

issues.author: arndt-s
issues.body:
I am going over a potential deployment of transaction tokens and a thought came into my mind: "Can I use Trats as a sole mean of authentication".

From what I remember our conversations the idea was always that transaction tokens would always be used in conjunction with workload authentication. I think we should add wording to section 8 Using Txn-Tokens to clarify this topic. Also, can they be used in conjunction with Access Tokens? Are there certain aspects/claims that need to match to be accepted?

In case we indeed want to allow txn tokens to be used as a sole authentication I'm pretty sure there's some security considerations to derive from that.

comments.body:
Thanks for raising this @arndt-s 

From discussions with the editors.

1. TraTs should not be used to authenticate a workload. It should be used with workload authentication. 
2. TraTs should not be presented along with Access Tokens. 
3. Trat's carries Authoriztion information. It should not be used for workload authentication. 

Decision: Add security considerations on workload-to-workload authentication. 

1. Use existing authentication methods
2. Don't use TraTs for authentication

issues.title: Classification of Txn tokens in an RBAC architecture
issues.author: salvisbh
issues.body:
We see in the proposal for transaction tokens the aim of establishing a badge that identifies the originating user throughout the workload call chain. In large business solutions, it is common practice to use functional roles for access control in addition to attributes of the originating user. In the proposal, we find no indication of how Txn-tokens interact with RBAC concepts.

Is it legitimate to supplement the optional rctx claim with roles? In our view, however, roles cannot be tailored in such scenario for the workload in question. We would rather see a variant in which the Txn-token service provides for a userinfo endpoint, via which a workload can obtain the functional roles in addition to further attributes of the subject context. Or are roles of the originating subject completely out-of-scope in the context of Txn tokens?

Has the Working Group given any thought to this issue?

Thank you for a clarification. It helps us to correctly position Txn-tokens within our security architecture.

comments.author: gffletch
comments.body:
Hi,

This is a very interesting question. I would probably recommend extending the `tctx` JSON object to contain additional constraints of the transaction. The `tctx` claim is intended to be extended for specific deployments. 

An important consideration is understand how the roles assigned to the subject affect the `purp` claim of the transaction token. I can envision scenarios where the roles have a much broader scope than the narrow purpose of this specific transaction. 

Finally, I’m not sure the TTS is the correct service to ask for ‘userinfo’ attributes. I’d instead recommend using a PDP that can pull that data from a Policy Information Point (PIP) as part of the dynamic authorization for the given workload. The “PDP” can be a sidecar to reduce latency issues.

Thanks,
George

comments.body:
Hello George
Thank you for your explanations. For me, these make sense and help us with our architectural picture. I draw the following conclusion:

- The Txn Token is a token that records the transaction context for a specific transaction of a specific subject
- The Txn Token can be expanded with new insights during further processing
- The Txn token can be used as input to the Policy Decision Point (PDP) to prepare the correct information for the specific transaction context so that the Policy Enforcement Point (PEP), or in our case a workload, can enforce with this PDP-Result the correct permissions in RBAC and ABAC. issues.title: Allow Proof-of-Possession (cnf claim) for Txn-Tokens
issues.author: dagdagdag83
issues.body:
My company is designing a new architecture for cloud inter-service security and we've realized a potentially powerful combination.

This is in relation to the WIMSE architecture. If you issue x.509 certificates as your Workload Identity Credentials (WIC), you can further use these certificates as input to a flow that supports mTLS client authentication (RFC8705), which will result in a certificate-bound token. Effectively though this token will be workload-bound because the WIC is bound to your workload identity.
Similarly you can do an application-level "dPoP-like" flow to get any tokens bounds to that key pair.

I argue that Txn-Tokens should allow, and mention, the possibility of using "cnf" claim as specified in RFC7800 to bind Txn-Tokens to workloads. This specification is already heavily aligned with WIMSE and makes ample mention of workloads. Of course this specification doesn't need to go into details of how this can relate to WIMSE or other patterns, it can just allow for the possibility and briefly mention it's use case.

issues.title: Consider replacing Scope with Purpose
issues.author: PieterKas
issues.body:
From the mailing list:

https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/oauth/tOA3lQDoiij0sPi7JI2nFDNOPbA/

[OAUTH-WG] Tx-Token Purpose vs Scope
Joe DeCock <joe@duendesoftware.com> Thu, 19 June 2025 22:44 UTC[Show header](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/oauth/tOA3lQDoiij0sPi7JI2nFDNOPbA/#)

Hello OAuth working group,

I've been reading the transaction tokens draft with great interest. I think
it's solving an important problem and largely I like what I'm seeing in the
draft. However, I think that the way that scope and purpose are
differentiated can be improved to make the specification easier to
understand, easier to implement, and improve interoperability.

The way that the purpose is described and contrasted with OAuth scopes in
section 5.2.1 makes good sense to me.

The purp claim captures the exact purpose of this particular transaction.
> This is often much narrower than a scope value issued to an external
> client. This is due to the fact that in most cases, the authorization model
> within the Trust Domain is quite different than the authorization model
> used with clients external to the Trust Domain. To that end, it is
> intentional to separate the concept of scope (often fairly coarse-grained)
> used with external clients from the purpose of the transaction used within
> the Trust Domain. How a given deployment represents the authorization model
> within the Trust Domain is out of scope for this specification.


But in the txn-token request (Section 7.1), the purpose of the transaction
token is sent as the scope parameter. I think that has the potential to be
confusing, because the two concepts are meant to be distinct. In my
experience, non-identity experts often struggle with the existing concepts
of scopes, claims, and roles. Reusing the scope parameter with purpose
semantics is likely going to be a cause for confusion.

Section 9.6 muddies the distinction between scope and purpose further:

The TTS MUST ensure that the requested purpose (scope) of the Txn-Token is
> equal or less than the scope(s) identified in the subject_token. This is
> also true of requesting a replacement Txn-Token. The TTS MUST ensure there
> is no unintentional increase in authorization scope.


It's not clear to me what the equal to or less than language exactly means,
but it's certainly very suggestive, perhaps in a way that isn't good. To
me, it makes it sound like a purpose is a part of a scope, or that there's
a relationship where certain scopes authorize certain purposes. It seems to
me that while the decision to issue a transaction token should take the
scope of the subject token into account, it potentially would also care
about other claims of the subject token, the calling client, the request
context, the request details, or the txn token service's policy.

My suggestions are to
1. Invent a new "purpose" parameter used to request transaction tokens so
that tx-token requests do not re-use scope or set it all,
2. Clarify the intentions of the "equal or less than" language in section
9.6, and
3. Consider language explicitly stating that transaction tokens MUST NOT
contain a scope claim.

The token exchange spec says that scope is optional, so I would simply
mandate that in a transaction token exchange, scope is not used.

Thinking about how I or others would likely implement this, it seems likely
that validating the purpose parameter as well as the configuration and
policy related to it would be a separate system from scope processing in
the AS. So, from an implementation point of view, adding the new parameter
would probably simplify the implementation at the AS. The new semantics and
parameters that are associated with the transaction token call would mean
that the client/initiating workload would already have to write some new
code. While existing libraries exist that know how to do token exchange in
general, the specifics of transaction tokens are still going to require
some implementation work. A new purpose parameter wouldn't add
significantly to that.

Language to ban scopes from transaction tokens would simply be there to
re-inforce what the specification is already (not) doing. It helps with
interoperability to make sure that the TTS never does include a scope, in
case a tx-token was ever misused. Of course we have the typ header to
differentiate the tokens, but leaving the scope out helps prevent their
misuse by older JWT libraries that don't know to validate the typ. And in
any case, it seems that not including the scope is the intention in this
draft.


Cheers,
Joe DeCock

issues.author: ashayraut
issues.body:
About req_wl in Requester Context {#requester-context}, especially during replacement, the document says "then this claim will be an array of StringOrURIs representing the different workloads that have requested Txn-Tokens as part of the transaction processing."

Why? Can we change the language to  - claim can be array ? can we leave it to implementation owners?

There are a few reasons why I want to be careful in adding all req_wls involved - 

1. Size - Tx Tokens are going to flow through HTTP headers. In my company, we are careful about size of the token as it flows through HTTP headers. Some web servers block 4KB or more headers and this could be problematic in propagation. If we keep adding all workload identities, then its size will increase. (unpredictable depending on call chain depth)
2. Token context governance - In general, its useful to only add information that could be useful for making authorization decisions, deep down the call graph. In reality, the services deep down call graph are not aware of all services in call path, so they can't really use write access policies using the req_wls anyways as it depends on what call path was taken to reach that service. Also Hyrum's law, that the more you add, the more ways, people will find to make it use of the data in different ways which may not be right.
3. I'd recommend to keep only latest information i.e last req_wl identity and let Token issuer log the exchange details against token identifier in its log to later audit all services where replacement happened.

Also created another issue to cover about having new token id every time there is replacement token generated. https://github.com/oauth-wg/oauth-transaction-tokens/issues/183

issues.title: Proposal for Tx token initiation in agentic world
issues.author: ashayraut
issues.body:
### Problem Statement

Authorization systems based on zero trust principles must rethink their approach when dealing with AI agents, as the characteristics that differentiate AI agents from traditional web services have major security implications. Unlike static web services, AI agents can act autonomously, adapt their behavior, and access or integrate with new data sources dynamically—sometimes making decisions outside of their originally intended scope. This means that existing zero trust models, which tightly define permissions, verification processes, and access scopes for regular web services, may fall short when applied to adaptive, context-aware AI agents. For true zero trust security, authorization systems should treat each AI agent interaction as potentially unique, inspect agent requests with greater granularity, and continuously evaluate both intent and context—not just identity. Dynamic policy enforcement, ongoing behavioral analysis, and robust audit mechanisms become critical to ensure that AI agents do not inadvertently gain unauthorized access or act outside governance boundaries, despite using the same foundational security model as for traditional web services.

Transaction Tokens are a solution to propagate security context across the call graph in the form of cryptographically signed tokens. These tokens start at the front of the call chain and are propagated through all services in the call chain. Services can leverage the security context for access control and auditing. 

To support AI agent applications in the service graph, Transaction Tokens need to address several challenges: where and how tokens will be generated, how context inputs are captured from agents, scoping/limiting the contexts for agents, ensuring token propagation, and updating the auditing process to capture agent identity along with original actor details.
Agents by default must be given zero permissions and must be able to get permissions only when delegated by human user. Unsupervised with no human in loop agents could get permissions based on the task but sensitive operations should have human in loop to approve. 

Agents could be in different environments including developer’s machine (unsafe environment) or hosted in CloudAuth with protected access.


### Assumptions
 
Before jumping into solution, an assumption is being made here that OAuth will be used for agentic interactions. Agents will have no permissions of their own but will request permissions from Authorization Server (AS) with human in the loop consenting it. Agents will basically have access token that calls the human user as subject and agent as ‘actor; representing that agent is acting on behalf of the user.

For multi-agent, another assumption is that each agent will do OAuth Token Exchange RFC 8693 for getting access token which indicates that the agent is acting on behalf of the previous agent. These access tokens will contain delegation chain information about all agent identities.

### Why not initiate Transaction tokens at the agents ?  

The obvious solution to ensure Transaction token coverage across entire call chain starting from agent is to initiate Transaction token at beginning of call chain, in this case, it will be the Agentic application. The agentic application will have OAuth access token to access a resource server, but before calling resource server (or workload), it will request Transaction token using the access token. Transaction Token Issuer (TTI) will issue Tx token by validating the input access token. The input access token will have information about agent and human identity. It will also prove that agent is acting on behalf of human. 

Challenges with initiating token at agents : 
There are multiple challenges in this approach. The agent to agent or agent to MCP server interaction can be long running and Transaction tokens will expire. So we have to figure out mechanism to keep Tx token refrehsed. Token propagation is another challenge over MCP/A2A and other protocols. The agents could be running in browser or relatively low secure environments such as a human user’s laptop which increases the risk of exposing our bearer Transaction token.


### Proposal: Initiate transaction tokens once agentic interaction is over. 

The core idea of shifting token generation away from potentially unsafe environments and onto a trusted server is compelling. Core design principle - The proposal simplifies agent logic by shifting complexity to the trusted, centralized infrastructure—the Authorization Server and the Transaction Token Issuer. 

Let's take this flow as an example - 

```
Human -> Agent A → MCP Server → Resource server → Internal Service (Resource Server)
```

- Human will invoke Agent. 
- Agent will take action by calling MCP Server. 
- MCP Server throws OAuth challenge 401 unauthorized. 
- Agent which is already registered with OAuth Authorization Server (AS) will request access token. 
- AS will invoke authorization code flow and ask human for consent. 
- Human approves it and then standard auth code flow starts. At the end, agent has access token that says agent is allowed to take action on behalf of subject (human). 
- MCP Server gets the access token. 
- MCP server has to call internal service now. MCP Server gets access token from agent, and then invoke OAuth Token Exchange RFC 8693 with AS and gets another access token. 
- AS verifies permissions of MCP server, access tokens and then issues access token to MCP Server. 
- This access token contains delegation chain including (human, agent, MCP Server). 
- 
- MCP Server now has access token with all delegation chain and about to call internal service. 
- This is where it should initiate Tx token by calling  Transaction Token Issuer (TTI) and passing the access token. 
- TTI will have all the necessary information to add in the Tx token using the access token as the access token has call chain information. 
- TTI must validate the access token before trusting it for generating Transaction token.
- The generated Transaction token will have the human identity as the Subject, the first agent identity as 'act' claim. It also aligns with https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/modelcontextprotocol/issues/214 


As supervised agents act on behalf of humans, its important to include their identity in the Transaction tokens. Whenever human triggers an agent, sub MUST contain human identity and there should be a new claim in the token to include identity of the agent that acts on behalf of the human user.


```
act: : OPTIONAL The "act" (actor) claim, within the context of OAuth 2.0 token exchange and JSON Web Tokens (JWTs), is defined in RFC 8693: OAuth 2.0 Token Exchange. The value will be the agent that is acting on behalf of the human user. In case the access token contains delegation chain, then it will be the first actor in 'act' field where this on behalf of flow started.
```

### Detailed explanation of the proposal
The core idea is that Transaction Tokens will leverage the OAuth Authorization Server-issued access tokens as proof to issue a Transaction Token. These access tokens will be issued to AI agent applications and MCP servers in the call chain. For agent-to-agent or agent-to-MCP server interactions, access tokens from agents all the way to the last MCP server/agent will carry delegation chain information. This means all identities involved up to that point will be present in these access tokens. This differs from the current service access token model where an access token from Service A to Service B is different from an access token issued by Service B to call Service C. 

The advantage of this approach is that now Tx tokens aren’t exposed to unsafe environments in which agents are running. If agents do have long running interactions, they will still maintain access tokens because most of the agents are supposed to be OAuth compliant. This gives Tx token RFC to be popular and get widely adopted but still not blocked on agents support Tx token. 
).

For mid-call chain use cases, 
```
Workload A(w/ Tx token) → MCP Server A → MCP Server B → Workload-2
```
where Transaction Token propagation through the service graph starts but agent-to-agent interaction begins, the first MCP server or agent  (MCP Server A in above example) will perform an OAuth token exchange to get onBehalfOf permissions, and the Transaction Token context could be preserved in the access token as a claim. So between MCP Server A → MCP Server B, access token is flowing but this access token was requested by MCP Server A as part of OAuth token exchange. In OAuth token exchange, MCP Server should send access token and Tx token as well to ensure access token captures the Tx token contents as claim. Before calling Workload-2, the access token can be used to get a Transaction Token at MCP Server B. TTI this time, instead of generating a token with new contexts, the preserved contexts from access token claim will be used. 

In summary, access tokens will be leveraged to procure Transaction Tokens. The OAuth token exchanged access tokens contain a delegation chain of identities, and when agent interaction starts in the middle of the call chain, access tokens will preserve Transaction Token contexts to get Transaction Tokens back when service interaction begins.

This approach for Transaction Tokens depends on OAuth Authorization Server support for OAuth token exchange, registering AI applications in the OAuth Authorization Server for identities, and delegation and permission models. The approach simplifies overall Transaction Token integration in this AI agent-based service graph as Transaction Tokens don't need to implement propagation over various protocols, or worry about issuing bearer tokens in unsafe environments such as developers' machines or browsers.

The agent-side space is rapidly evolving, and by moving Transaction Token generation to the server side, integration stays simple while the OAuth Authorization Server handles the complexity. This approach assumes that all relevant protocols are or will be supporting OAuth, including agent applications. This means that agent application frameworks that support OAuth should be sufficient for AI agent apps to start development and launch, instead of integrating Transaction Tokens explicitly in their agent code and further complicating it.

### Security and additional considerations

- I acknowledge that while the risk of exposing a Transaction Token is removed, the risk of a compromised OAuth Access Token remains. Advocate for mTLS as a non-negotiable security measure for all inter-service communication to protect against this.

- We should consider may be new, standardized claim to the oauth-transaction-tokens working group for transporting Transaction Token context within an access token. This ensures interoperability and prevents proprietary implementations.

- We must mandate that all audit trails for AI agent interactions include the full delegation chain (human, agent), along with all dynamic business context used to make a decision.

comments.author: tulshi
comments.body:
I know @gffletch is working on this, but here are my thoughts:

The `purp` claim is named differently from the similarly used `scope` claim in OAuth access tokens because:

1. OAuth access token scopes are permissions granted to an OAuth client in order to access resources (after receiving consent from the user in most cases). This is different from the `purp` of a Transaction Token, which specifies permissions for the specific transaction. It does not include user consent, and it is decoupled from what the OAuth client may have access to as a result of the `scope` in the incoming OAuth access token (if one is present).
2. Using the same term `scope` for two different domains as described above can cause confusion among users who often have to deal with both systems - those that use/issue OAuth access tokens, and those that use/issue Transaction Tokens
3. The `purp` claim is expected to contain finer grained permissions than a `scope` in an OAuth access token. This is because a specific set of permissions may be approved (automatically by relevant policy components) for the short duration of that Transaction Token, and such approval is codified in the `purp`, whereas the `scope` in a long-lived OAuth access token may represent all possible permissions a user may require over the lifetime of that access token.

issues.title: purpose containing multiple space-delimited strings
issues.author: obfuscoder
issues.body:
From OAuth RFC, we know that scope is a list of strings (space-separated) where each string (a.k.a. scope-token) represents a separate access granted with the Access Token. The order of the scope-tokens does not matter. They are not related.  (See https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc6749#section-3.3). Resource servers may only require one particular scope-token to be present while ignoring all the others.

I understand that the purpose of the Txn-Token is rather unique. It defines the specific operation to be performed. Yet, the transaction token draft also defines this value as a list of space-separated strings. My current understanding is that those strings are actually related and that the order is important contrary to how scope for Access Tokens works. I think the purpose value should not be seen as a list of strings, but rather seen in its entirety as a unique value defining the overall operation being performed. So I think it may cause confusion if we actually allowed space in the purpose value as implementers might assume the content is interpreted similar to scope.

comments.author: gffletch
comments.body:
This again gets to the authorization model within the trust domain. Do all workloads receiving the transaction token understand all single-value purpose strings (now `scope`) or are they looking for something more narrow that applies to the specific workload? Maybe we could recommend just using one value? but I think it depends on how the authorization model works in the trust domain whether multiple are needed or not. This is why the Transaction Token Service is authoritative for the value(s) in that claim.

One of the hard parts of defining transaction tokens is the lack of consistent deployed authorization models :)

issues.title: Relation of purpose to scope validated at API gateway
issues.author: obfuscoder
issues.body:
An Access Token can contain multiple scope-tokens where only one or two may be required to call a specific API gateway endpoint. The API gateway endpoint validates whether a specific scope-value is present in the presented Access Token before performing the operation. The Txn-Token-Service is being presented with this AccessToken and the scope request parameter defines the purpose of the Txn-Token to be issued. I wonder if it would make sense to use the scope request parameter to let the Txn-Token-Service know what particular scope-token of the presented Access Token was granting the access to the API gateway endpoint and use another request parameter (purp) to actually define the purpose of the Txn-Token.

This would allow the Txn-Token request to be a profile of Token Exchange while clearly separating scope and purpose request parameters.

Example:

- Client presents AT with scope "mail storage addressbook" which essentially grants access to the different API gateways of those respective systems.
- The API gateway for mail receives this AT and validates that the AT contains the scope-token "mail".
- The mail API gateway is requesting a Txn-Token with the purpose of sending a mail. The purpose value "send-mail" is being requested. To signal the Txn-Token-Service which scope-token was validated at the API gateway, the Txn-Token request contains the value "mail" in the scope parameter and the value "send-mail" will be in the "purp" request parameter.
- The Txn-Token-Service can now validate if the "scope" request parameter is actually contained within the AT and it can determine whether the requested purpose is derivable from the specific scope value.

comments.author: gffletch
comments.body:
This use case makes sense from an authorization perspective. However, this also gets to the point that pretty much every deployment has it's own unique authorization model.  I'm not sure how we cover all possibilities.

Is it acceptable to only define the `scope` parameter and let specific deployments extend to say include an extra parameter that is unique to that authorization model (i.e. for this case add an implementation defined `purp` claim).

I could also see just setting the `scope` parameter to `send-mail` and then ensuring the TTS has the authorization validation logic to ensure the access token contains the `mail` scope as one of the specified scopes.

comments.body: @gffletch With the replacement of "purp" with "scope", can we close this issue?
